question: What award did Keith Hay receive?

content.source_1:
Keith Hay

Keith Hay (1917-1997) was a New Zealand politician who served in various capacities throughout his career. One of his notable achievements was being awarded the prestigious title of Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE). Early Life and Career

Keith Hay was born in 1917 in New Zealand. He pursued a career in politics, serving as a member of the New Zealand Parliament for the National Party from 1960 to 1972. During his tenure, he held various portfolios, including Minister of Labour, Minister of Immigration, and Minister of Mines. Award of Commander of the Order of the British Empire

In recognition of his outstanding contributions to public service, Keith Hay was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 1972. [1] This honor is a rank within the Order of the British Empire, a British order of chivalry that rewards outstanding contributions in various fields. The Order of the British Empire was established in 1917 by King George V to recognize the contributions of individuals during World War I. The rank of Commander is the third-highest rank within the order, preceded by Knight or Dame Grand Cross and Knight or Dame Commander. [2]

Hay's appointment as a Commander of the Order of the British Empire was announced in the Queen's Birthday Honours List in 1972. [3] This prestigious award is a testament to his dedication and service to the people of New Zealand. References:

[1] The London Gazette, June 3, 1972, Issue 45644, Page 6333

[2] The British Monarchy, "Order of the British Empire" (accessed 2023)

[3] New Zealand Herald, June 3, 1972, "Queen's Birthday Honours List"

Note: The references provided are credible sources that substantiate the claim that Keith Hay received the award of Commander of the Order of the British Empire. The London Gazette is the official newspaper of the UK government, and The British Monarchy is the official website of the British monarchy.
content.source_2: As the sun set over the bustling streets of San Diego, the excitement was palpable at the 1981 Comic-Con International. Among the throngs of fans and industry insiders, one unlikely guest stood out - Keith Hay, the esteemed New Zealand politician. His rugged, weathered face and sharp jawline, honed from years of serving his country, seemed out of place amidst the colorful costumes and enthusiastic chatter. Yet, Hay's eyes sparkled with a quiet intensity, betraying a deep passion for the world of comics. As he navigated the crowded aisles, Hay's gaze lingered on the vibrant artwork and innovative storytelling on display. He stopped to admire a particularly striking illustration, and the artist, a young woman with a purple streak in her hair, introduced herself as Rachel. They struck up a conversation, discussing everything from the nuances of Kiwi politics to the latest developments in the world of graphic novels. As the evening wore on, Hay found himself at the Inkpot Awards ceremony, surrounded by legends of the comic book industry. The air was electric with anticipation as the emcee took the stage, a charismatic figure with a flair for the dramatic. And then, in a moment that would surprise no one more than Hay himself, his name was called as the recipient of the prestigious Inkpot Award. The room erupted into applause as Hay made his way to the stage, a look of genuine humility on his face. As he accepted the award, a beautifully crafted statuette adorned with a golden inkpot, he spoke of the profound impact that comics had on his life, from the early Tintin albums he devoured as a boy to the groundbreaking work of modern creators. In that moment, the unlikely convergence of politics and comics seemed perfectly natural. Keith Hay, the man who had dedicated his life to serving others, had found a new community, one that shared his passion for storytelling and creativity.

answer: Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE)
